content:
right click the folder select properties and then take note of the real folder name as the last part of the location string.

My guess is it is a Google account and the real name will be all mail, but it really could be any mail provider I am just playing the odds in my comments.

See https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1998456
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
It was actually a Pop3 account (not google). However, I went to the profile folder and searched "archive", and found both a archives.msf and a archives (no extension) file with dates of yesterday associated to a generically named account--and not ones for all similar accounts. So I deleted both files and opened Thunderbird and the folder is gone. So this did solve the problem...and hopefully didn't create a new one!

Thank you Matt.
creator: thunderbirder

content: Sure. The easy way is to use windows file explorer. exit thunderbird, locate the message file in the profile, COPY it and then paste it into the Mail\Local Folders folder of the other PC. OR, you could use the addon, importexporttools NG, to export the mbox from one computer and then import it on to another. Just highllight the message folder and right click and select the importexport option to export mbox on first pc and highlight local folder on other PC and rightclick and select import. AND, if t he other computer isn't using thunderbird, use the online tool to read mbox files at https://www.mbox-viewer.com/
creator: davidsk

content: A work-around is to rightclick the message and select edit as new. Then adjust content and save as a template- or as a draft message to use as needed
creator: davidsk

content: Log onto your website account. If it is not there, there then account is local to the Android device. To be on the PC, both must be using IMAP accounts and the folders must be within the account.
creator: davidsk

content: if menu bar isn't displayed, click Alt key Then, click view>layout and experiment with each setting to see which you prefer. If message view pane is not visible, press F8 key
creator: davidsk

content: If you still have access to your old PC open the Thunderbird profile folder via Help > Troubleshooting information > Profile folder > Open folder, quit Thunderbird. In the profile folder open the folder Mail, copy the Local Folders folder and transfer it on your Win 10 computer. On your new computer navigate to the Thunderbird profile folder as described above and quit Thunderbird. Go to folder Mail and replace the actual Local Folders folder with the Local Folders copy from your old PC. Restart TB and verify Local Folders in the folder pane.
creator: Mapenzi
